content: The "Today's Entrepreneurs are America's Mentors Act" or the "TEAM Act" defines terms related to small business concerns and establishes an Office of Entrepreneurial Education within the Small Business Administration. The "TEAM Act" establishes the Office of Entrepreneurial Education within the Small Business Administration to provide innovative entrepreneurial information and resources to promote prospective entrepreneurs and successful small business concerns. The Director of the Office manages online courses and publications for entrepreneurs and small business concerns. The Office of Entrepreneurial Education within the Small Business Administration manages youth entrepreneurship programs, coordinates with partners for financial literacy education, and provides assistance to entrepreneurs and small business concerns. The Small Business Administration's Office of Entrepreneurial Education offers assistance and courtesy services to individuals and foreign dignitaries interested in entrepreneurship. Additionally, they establish a National Primary and Secondary School Entrepreneurial Education Program, providing grants to nonprofit organizations for entrepreneurial development. The Small Business Administration's Office of Entrepreneurial Education offers grants to nonprofit organizations for entrepreneurial development in primary and secondary schools. Nonprofit organizations must submit an application outlining project goals and partners involved. A report is required within one year of receiving the grant. The nonprofit organization receiving a grant must submit a report within 1 year detailing the individuals assisted, jobs created or saved, and any other required information. $3,000,000 is authorized for fiscal years 2013-2015. The Director of the Office of Entrepreneurial Education must submit a report within 180 days detailing best practices of entrepreneurial education and training programs in the US, including exemplary national, regional, state, and local programs. The report must detail best practices of entrepreneurial education and training programs in the US, including programs by the Federal Government, State and local governments, nonprofit organizations, and private sector groups. SEC. 4. UNIVERSITY AND COLLEGE ENTREPRENEURIAL EDUCATION PROGRAM. Section 21 of the Small Business Act is amended to allow small business development centers to apply for grants to implement university and college entrepreneurial education programs. These programs can involve connecting students with small businesses, assisting faculty with entrepreneurial education, and more. The Small Business Act is amended to allow small business development centers to apply for grants to implement university and college entrepreneurial education programs, including improving curricula and developing entrepreneurial education programs. Grants may be subject to funding provided in advance in appropriations Acts. SEC. 46. ENTREPRENEURIAL INNOVATORS PARTNERSHIP PROGRAM. The Small Business Act is amended to establish a partnership program for entrepreneurial innovators. The Associate Administrator will establish an entrepreneurial innovators partnership program, providing grants to nonprofit organizations to support innovative programs that promote entrepreneurship, enhance partnerships with entrepreneurs, and stimulate job creation by small businesses. The Associate Administrator will provide grants up to $250,000 for programs promoting entrepreneurship among youth, veterans, MBA students offering free assistance to small businesses, entrepreneurial education for professional service providers, and other approved programs. The Federal share of project costs under the grant program cannot exceed 50%, unless the project helps a program become self-sustaining or creates at least 100 new jobs. Eligible entities must submit grant applications to the Associate Administrator. The Associate Administrator determines grant application requirements and gives priority to innovative proposals, entities with success in job creation, small business growth, or partnerships with nonprofits and educational institutions. Authorization of Appropriations: $3,000,000 for each of fiscal years 2013, 2014, and 2015. SEC. 6. REGIONAL ENTREPRENEURIAL COMPETITIONS. The Administrator will establish a program for regional competitions and a national conference to address challenges through entrepreneurial research and business planning. Regional offices will identify issues, sponsor competitions for small businesses, and collaborate with universities. The Administrator will organize a national conference to promote a competition for research and business plans that address identified issues. The Administrator will organize a national conference to present selected research and business plans. A panel of 11 employees will choose the best plan from each region addressing identified issues. The Administrator will award a $50,000 grant to selected plans from the national conference. Recipients must submit a report on grant usage within a year. $750,000 is authorized for Administrator's use. The Administrator will receive $750,000 for carrying out this section. The Administrator, in consultation with the Secretary of Education, will submit a report to Congress within 180 days of the Act's enactment. The report will include recommendations for legislation to forgive and defer student loans to support youth entrepreneurship by providing capital for business formation.
